play.title: The Tragedy of Richard the Third

scene.scenepersonae: (Richard Duke of Gloucester, Clarence, Brakenbury, Lord Hastings)
scene.stagedir: Enter Richard Duke of Gloucester solus.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Now is the winter of our discontent
Made glorious summer by this son of York;
And all the clouds that low’r’d upon our house
In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.
Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths,
Our bruised arms hung up for monuments,
Our stern alarums chang’d to merry meetings,
Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.
Grim-visag’d War hath smooth’d his wrinkled front;
And now, in stead of mounting barbed steeds
To fright the souls of fearful adversaries,
He capers nimbly in a lady’s chamber
To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.
But I, that am not shap’d for sportive tricks,
Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass;
I, that am rudely stamp’d, and want love’s majesty
To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;
I, that am curtail’d of this fair proportion,
Cheated of feature by dissembling nature,
Deform’d, unfinish’d, sent before my time
Into this breathing world, scarce half made up,
And that so lamely and unfashionable
That dogs bark at me as I halt by them—
Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace,
Have no delight to pass away the time,
Unless to see my shadow in the sun
And descant on mine own deformity.
And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover
To entertain these fair well-spoken days,
I am determined to prove a villain
And hate the idle pleasures of these days.
Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous,
By drunken prophecies, libels, and dreams,
To set my brother Clarence and the King
In deadly hate the one against the other;
And if King Edward be as true and just
As I am subtle, false, and treacherous,
This day should Clarence closely be mew’d up
About a prophecy, which says that G
Of Edward’s heirs the murderer shall be.
Dive, thoughts, down to my soul, here Clarence comes!
speech.stagedir: Enter Clarence, guarded, and Brakenbury, Lieutenant of the Tower.
speech.line: Brother, good day. What means this armed guard
That waits upon your Grace?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: His Majesty,
Tend’ring my person’s safety, hath appointed
This conduct to convey me to the Tower.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Upon what cause?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Because my name is George.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours;
He should for that commit your godfathers.
O, belike his Majesty hath some intent
That you should be new christ’ned in the Tower.
But what’s the matter, Clarence, may I know?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Yea, Richard, when I know; but I protest
As yet I do not. But, as I can learn,
He hearkens after prophecies and dreams,
And from the cross-row plucks the letter G,
And says a wizard told him that by G
His issue disinherited should be;
And for my name of George begins with G,
It follows in his thought that I am he.
These (as I learn) and such-like toys as these
Hath mov’d his Highness to commit me now.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Why, this it is, when men are rul’d by women:
’Tis not the King that sends you to the Tower;
My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, ’tis she
That tempers him to this extremity.
Was it not she, and that good man of worship,
Anthony Woodvile, her brother there,
That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower,
From whence this present day he is delivered?
We are not safe, Clarence, we are not safe.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: By heaven, I think there is no man is secure
But the Queen’s kindred, and night-walking heralds
That trudge betwixt the King and Mistress Shore.
Heard you not what an humble suppliant
Lord Hastings was to her for his delivery?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Humbly complaining to her deity
Got my Lord Chamberlain his liberty.
I’ll tell you what, I think it is our way,
If we will keep in favor with the King,
To be her men and wear her livery.
The jealous o’erworn widow and herself,
Since that our brother dubb’d them gentlewomen,
Are mighty gossips in our monarchy.

speech.speaker: BRAK.
speech.line: I beseech your Graces both to pardon me:
His Majesty hath straitly given in charge
That no man shall have private conference
(Of what degree soever) with your brother.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Even so? And please your worship, Brakenbury,
You may partake of any thing we say:
We speak no treason, man. We say the King
Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen
Well strook in years, fair, and not jealious;
We say that Shore’s wife hath a pretty foot,
A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue;
And that the Queen’s kindred are made gentlefolks.
How say you, sir? Can you deny all this?

speech.speaker: BRAK.
speech.line: With this, my lord, myself have nought to do.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Naught to do with Mistress Shore? I tell thee, fellow,
He that doth naught with her (excepting one)
Were best to do it secretly alone.

speech.speaker: BRAK.
speech.line: What one, my lord?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Her husband, knave. Wouldst thou betray me?

speech.speaker: BRAK.
speech.line: I do beseech your Grace to pardon me, and withal
Forbear your conference with the noble Duke.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: We are the Queen’s abjects, and must obey.
Brother, farewell, I will unto the King,
And whatsoe’er you will employ me in,
Were it to call King Edward’s widow sister,
I will perform it to enfranchise you.
Mean time, this deep disgrace in brotherhood
Touches me deeper than you can imagine.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long,
I will deliver you, or else lie for you.
Mean time, have patience.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: I must perforce. Farewell.

scene.stagedir: Exit Clarence with Brakenbury and Guard.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Go tread the path that thou shalt ne’er return:
Simple plain Clarence, I do love thee so
That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven,
If heaven will take the present at our hands.
But who comes here? The new-delivered Hastings?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: Good time of day unto my gracious lord!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: As much unto my good Lord Chamberlain!
Well are you welcome to the open air.
How hath your lordship brook’d imprisonment?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must;
But I shall live, my lord, to give them thanks
That were the cause of my imprisonment.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: No doubt, no doubt, and so shall Clarence too,
For they that were your enemies are his,
And have prevail’d as much on him as you.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: More pity that the eagles should be mew’d,
Whiles kites and buzzards prey at liberty.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: What news abroad?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: No news so bad abroad as this at home:
The King is sickly, weak, and melancholy,
And his physicians fear him mightily.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Now by Saint John, that news is bad indeed!
O, he hath kept an evil diet long,
And overmuch consum’d his royal person:
’Tis very grievous to be thought upon.
Where is he? In his bed?

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: He is.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Go you before, and I will follow you.
He cannot live, I hope, and must not die
Till George be pack’d with post-horse up to heaven.
I’ll in, to urge his hatred more to Clarence
With lies well steel’d with weighty arguments,
And if I fail not in my deep intent,
Clarence hath not another day to live:
Which done, God take King Edward to his mercy,
And leave the world for me to bustle in!
For then I’ll marry Warwick’s youngest daughter.
What though I kill’d her husband and her father?
The readiest way to make the wench amends
Is to become her husband and her father:
The which will I, not all so much for love
As for another secret close intent
By marrying her which I must reach unto.
But yet I run before my horse to market:
Clarence still breathes, Edward still lives and reigns;
When they are gone, then must I count my gains.

scene.scenepersonae: (Henry the Sixth, Halberds, Lady Anne, Tressel, Berkeley, Richard Duke of Gloucester)
scene.stagedir: Enter the corpse of Henry the Sixth, with Halberds to guard it, Lady Anne being the mourner, attended by Tressel and Berkeley.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Set down, set down your honorable load,
If honor may be shrouded in a hearse,
Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament
Th’ untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster.
Poor key-cold figure of a holy king,
Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster,
Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood,
Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost
To hear the lamentations of poor Anne,
Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaught’red son,
Stabb’d by the self-same hand that made these wounds!
Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life
I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes.
O, cursed be the hand that made these holes!
Cursed the heart that had the heart to do it!
Cursed the blood that let this blood from hence!
More direful hap betide that hated wretch
That makes us wretched by the death of thee
Than I can wish to wolves—to spiders, toads,
Or any creeping venom’d thing that lives!
If ever he have child, abortive be it,
Prodigious, and untimely brought to light,
Whose ugly and unnatural aspect
May fright the hopeful mother at the view,
And that be heir to his unhappiness!
If ever he have wife, let her be made
More miserable by the life of him
Than I am made by my young lord and thee!
Come now towards Chertsey with your holy load,
Taken from Paul’s to be interred there;
And still as you are weary of this weight,
Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry’s corse.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Stay, you that bear the corse, and set it down.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: What black magician conjures up this fiend
To stop devoted charitable deeds?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Villains, set down the corse, or, by Saint Paul,
I’ll make a corse of him that disobeys.

speech.speaker: GENTLEMAN.
speech.line: My lord, stand back, and let the coffin pass.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Unmanner’d dog, stand thou when I command.
Advance thy halberd higher than my breast,
Or by Saint Paul I’ll strike thee to my foot,
And spurn upon thee, beggar, for thy boldness.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: What do you tremble? Are you all afraid?
Alas, I blame you not, for you are mortal,
And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil.—
Avaunt, thou dreadful minister of hell!
Thou hadst but power over his mortal body,
His soul thou canst not have. Therefore be gone.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Foul devil, for God’s sake hence, and trouble us not,
For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell,
Fill’d it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.
If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds,
Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.
O gentlemen, see, see dead Henry’s wounds
Open their congeal’d mouths and bleed afresh!
Blush, blush, thou lump of foul deformity;
For ’tis thy presence that exhales this blood
From cold and empty veins where no blood dwells.
Thy deeds inhuman and unnatural
Provokes this deluge most unnatural.
O God! Which this blood mad’st, revenge his death!
O earth! Which this blood drink’st, revenge his death!
Either heav’n with lightning strike the murth’rer dead;
Or earth gape open wide and eat him quick,
As thou dost swallow up this good king’s blood,
Which his hell-govern’d arm hath butchered!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Lady, you know no rules of charity,
Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Villain, thou know’st nor law of God nor man:
No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: But I know none, and therefore am no beast.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: O wonderful, when devils tell the troth!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: More wonderful, when angels are so angry.
Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman,
Of these supposed crimes, to give me leave
By circumstance but to acquit myself.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Vouchsafe, defus’d infection of a man,
Of these known evils, but to give me leave
By circumstance t’ accuse thy cursed self.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have
Some patient leisure to excuse myself.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst make
No excuse current but to hang thyself.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: By such despair I should accuse myself.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: And by despairing shalt thou stand excused
For doing worthy vengeance on thyself,
That didst unworthy slaughter upon others.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Say that I slew them not?

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Then say they were not slain.
But dead they are, and, devilish slave, by thee.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I did not kill your husband.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Why then he is alive.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Nay, he is dead, and slain by Edward’s hands.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: In thy foul throat thou li’st! Queen Margaret saw
Thy murd’rous falchion smoking in his blood;
The which thou once didst bend against her breast,
But that thy brothers beat aside the point.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I was provoked by her sland’rous tongue,
That laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind,
That never dream’st on aught but butcheries.
Didst thou not kill this king?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I grant ye.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Dost grant me, hedgehog? Then God grant me too
Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed!
O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: The better for the King of Heaven that hath him.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Let him thank me that holp to send him thither;
For he was fitter for that place than earth.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: And thou unfit for any place, but hell.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Some dungeon.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Your bedchamber.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Ill rest betide the chamber where thou liest!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: So will it, madam, till I lie with you.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I hope so.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I know so. But, gentle Lady Anne,
To leave this keen encounter of our wits
And fall something into a slower method:
Is not the causer of the timeless deaths
Of these Plantagenets, Henry and Edward,
As blameful as the executioner?

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Thou wast the cause, and most accurs’d effect.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Your beauty was the cause of that effect—
Your beauty, that did haunt me in my sleep
To undertake the death of all the world,
So I might live one hour in your sweet bosom.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: If I thought that, I tell thee, homicide,
These nails should rent that beauty from my cheeks.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: These eyes could not endure that beauty’s wrack;
You should not blemish it, if I stood by:
As all the world is cheered by the sun,
So I by that; it is my day, my life.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Black night o’ershade thy day, and death thy life!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Curse not thyself, fair creature—thou art both.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I would I were, to be reveng’d on thee.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: It is a quarrel most unnatural,
To be reveng’d on him that loveth thee.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: It is a quarrel just and reasonable,
To be reveng’d on him that kill’d my husband.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: He that bereft thee, lady, of thy husband,
Did it to help thee to a better husband.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: His better doth not breathe upon the earth.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: He lives, that loves thee better than he could.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Name him.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Plantagenet.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Why, that was he.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: The self-same name, but one of better nature.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Where is he?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Here.
Why dost thou spit at me?

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Would it were mortal poison for thy sake!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Never came poison from so sweet a place.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Never hung poison on a fouler toad.
Out of my sight, thou dost infect mine eyes!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Would they were basilisks, to strike thee dead!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I would they were, that I might die at once;
For now they kill me with a living death.
Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears,
Sham’d their aspects with store of childish drops:
These eyes, which never shed remorseful tear—
No, when my father York and Edward wept
To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made
When black-fac’d Clifford shook his sword at him;
Nor when thy warlike father, like a child,
Told the sad story of my father’s death,
And twenty times made pause to sob and weep,
That all the standers-by had wet their cheeks
Like trees bedash’d with rain—in that sad time
My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear;
And what these sorrows could not thence exhale,
Thy beauty hath, and made them blind with weeping.
I never sued to friend nor enemy;
My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word;
But now thy beauty is propos’d my fee,
My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak.
Teach not thy lip such scorn; for it was made
For kissing, lady, not for such contempt.
If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive,
Lo here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword,
Which if thou please to hide in this true breast,
And let the soul forth that adoreth thee,
I lay it naked to the deadly stroke,
And humbly beg the death upon my knee.
speech.stagedir: He lays his breast open: she offers at it with his sword.
speech.line: Nay, do not pause: for I did kill King Henry—
But ’twas thy beauty that provoked me.
Nay, now dispatch: ’twas I that stabb’d young Edward
But ’twas thy heavenly face that set me on.
Take up the sword again, or take up me.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Arise, dissembler! Though I wish thy death,
I will not be thy executioner.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Then bid me kill myself, and I will do it.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I have already.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: That was in thy rage.
Speak it again, and even with the word
This hand, which for thy love did kill thy love,
Shall for thy love kill a far truer love;
To both their deaths shalt thou be accessary.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I would I knew thy heart.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: ’Tis figur’d in my tongue.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: I fear me both are false.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Then never was man true.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: Well, well, put up your sword.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Say then my peace is made.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: That shalt thou know hereafter.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: But shall I live in hope?

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: All men, I hope, live so.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Vouchsafe to wear this ring.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: To take is not to give.

scene.stagedir: Gloucester slips the ring on her finger.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Look how my ring encompasseth thy finger,
Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart:
Wear both of them, for both of them are thine.
And if thy poor devoted servant may
But beg one favor at thy gracious hand,
Thou dost confirm his happiness forever.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: What is it?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: That it may please you leave these sad designs
To him that hath most cause to be a mourner,
And presently repair to Crosby House;
Where (after I have solemnly interr’d
At Chertsey monast’ry this noble king,
And wet his grave with my repentant tears)
I will with all expedient duty see you.
For divers unknown reasons, I beseech you,
Grant me this boon.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: With all my heart, and much it joys me too,
To see you are become so penitent.
Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Bid me farewell.

speech.speaker: ANNE.
speech.line: ’Tis more than you deserve;
But since you teach me how to flatter you,
Imagine I have said farewell already.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt two, Tressel and Berkeley, with Anne.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Sirs, take up the corse.

speech.speaker: GENT.
speech.line: Towards Chertsey, noble lord?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: No; to White-Friars, there attend my coming.
Was ever woman in this humor woo’d?
Was ever woman in this humor won?
I’ll have her, but I will not keep her long.
What? I, that kill’d her husband and his father,
To take her in her heart’s extremest hate,
With curses in her mouth, tears in her eyes,
The bleeding witness of my hatred by,
Having God, her conscience, and these bars against me,
And I no friends to back my suit at all
But the plain devil and dissembling looks?
And yet to win her! All the world to nothing!
Hah!
Hath she forgot already that brave prince,
Edward, her lord, whom I, some three months since,
Stabb’d in my angry mood at Tewksbury?
A sweeter and a lovelier gentleman,
Fram’d in the prodigality of nature—
Young, valiant, wise, and (no doubt) right royal—
The spacious world cannot again afford.
And will she yet abase her eyes on me,
That cropp’d the golden prime of this sweet prince
And made her widow to a woeful bed?
On me, whose all not equals Edward’s moi’ty?
On me, that halts and am misshapen thus?
My dukedom to a beggarly denier,
I do mistake my person all this while!
Upon my life, she finds (although I cannot)
Myself to be a marv’llous proper man.
I’ll be at charges for a looking-glass,
And entertain a score or two of tailors
To study fashions to adorn my body:
Since I am crept in favor with myself,
I will maintain it with some little cost.
But first I’ll turn yon fellow in his grave,
And then return lamenting to my love.
Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass,
That I may see my shadow as I pass.

scene.scenepersonae: (Queen Mother Elizabeth, Lord Rivers, Marquess of Dorset, Lord Grey, Buckingham, Lord Stanley, Richard Duke of Gloucester, Lord Hastings, Queen Margaret, Catesby, Murderers)
scene.stagedir: Enter the Queen Mother Elizabeth, Lord Rivers, Marquess of Dorset, and Lord Grey.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: Have patience, madam, there’s no doubt his Majesty
Will soon recover his accustom’d health.

speech.speaker: GREY.
speech.line: In that you brook it ill, it makes him worse;
Therefore for God’s sake entertain good comfort,
And cheer his Grace with quick and merry eyes.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: If he were dead, what would betide on me?

speech.speaker: GREY.
speech.line: No other harm but loss of such a lord.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: The loss of such a lord includes all harms.

speech.speaker: GREY.
speech.line: The heavens have blest you with a goodly son
To be your comforter when he is gone.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Ah! He is young; and his minority
Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester,
A man that loves not me, nor none of you.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: Is it concluded he shall be Protector?

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: It is determin’d, not concluded yet;
But so it must be, if the King miscarry.

scene.stagedir: Enter Buckingham and Lord Stanley, Earl of Derby.

speech.speaker: GREY.
speech.line: Here come the lords of Buckingham and Derby.

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: Good time of day unto your royal Grace!

speech.speaker: STAN.
speech.line: God make your Majesty joyful, as you have been!

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: The Countess Richmond, good my Lord of Derby,
To your good prayer will scarcely say amen.
Yet, Derby, notwithstanding she’s your wife
And loves not me, be you, good lord, assur’d
I hate not you for her proud arrogance.

speech.speaker: STAN.
speech.line: I do beseech you, either not believe
The envious slanders of her false accusers;
Or if she be accus’d on true report,
Bear with her weakness, which I think proceeds
From wayward sickness and no grounded malice.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Saw you the King today, my Lord of Derby?

speech.speaker: STAN.
speech.line: But now the Duke of Buckingham and I
Are come from visiting his Majesty.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: What likelihood of his amendment, lords?

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: Madam, good hope, his Grace speaks cheerfully.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: God grant him health! Did you confer with him?

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: Ay, madam, he desires to make atonement
Between the Duke of Gloucester and your brothers,
And between them and my Lord Chamberlain,
And sent to warn them to his royal presence.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Would all were well! But that will never be:
I fear our happiness is at the height.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard Duke of Gloucester and Lord Hastings.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: They do me wrong, and I will not endure it!
Who is it that complains unto the King
That I, forsooth, am stern, and love them not?
By holy Paul, they love his Grace but lightly
That fill his ears with such dissentious rumors.
Because I cannot flatter and look fair,
Smile in men’s faces, smooth, deceive, and cog,
Duck with French nods and apish courtesy,
I must be held a rancorous enemy.
Cannot a plain man live and think no harm,
But thus his simple truth must be abus’d
With silken, sly, insinuating Jacks?

speech.speaker: GREY.
speech.line: To who in all this presence speaks your Grace?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace:
When have I injur’d thee? When done thee wrong?
Or thee? Or thee? Or any of your faction?
A plague upon you all! His royal Grace
(Whom God preserve better than you would wish!)
Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing while
But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter:
The King, on his own royal disposition
(And not provok’d by any suitor else),
Aiming, belike, at your interior hatred,
That in your outward action shows itself
Against my children, brothers, and myself,
Makes him to send, that he may learn the ground.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I cannot tell, the world is grown so bad
That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch.
Since every Jack became a gentleman,
There’s many a gentle person made a Jack.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Come, come, we know your meaning, brother Gloucester;
You envy my advancement and my friends’.
God grant we never may have need of you!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Mean time, God grants that I have need of you.
Our brother is imprison’d by your means,
Myself disgrac’d, and the nobility
Held in contempt, while great promotions
Are daily given to ennoble those
That scarce some two days since were worth a noble.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: By Him that rais’d me to this careful height
From that contented hap which I enjoy’d,
I never did incense his Majesty
Against the Duke of Clarence, but have been
An earnest advocate to plead for him.
My lord, you do me shameful injury
Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: You may deny that you were not the mean
Of my Lord Hastings’ late imprisonment.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: She may, my lord, for—

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: She may, Lord Rivers! Why, who knows not so?
She may do more, sir, than denying that:
She may help you to many fair preferments,
And then deny her aiding hand therein
And lay those honors on your high desert.
What may she not, she may, ay, marry, may she.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: What, marry, may she?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: What, marry, may she? Marry with a king,
A bachelor, and a handsome stripling too:
Iwis your grandam had a worser match.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne
Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs.
By heaven, I will acquaint his Majesty
Of those gross taunts that oft I have endur’d.
I had rather be a country servant maid
Than a great queen with this condition,
To be so baited, scorn’d, and stormed at.
Small joy have I in being England’s queen.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: And less’ned be that small, God I beseech him!
Thy honor, state, and seat is due to me.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: What? Threat you me with telling of the King?
Tell him, and spare not. Look what I have said,
I will avouch’t in presence of the King.
I dare adventure to be sent to th’ Tow’r.
’Tis time to speak, my pains are quite forgot.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Out, devil! I do remember them too well:
Thou kill’dst my husband Henry in the Tower,
And Edward, my poor son, at Tewksbury.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Ere you were queen, ay, or your husband king,
I was a pack-horse in his great affairs:
A weeder-out of his proud adversaries,
A liberal rewarder of his friends;
To royalize his blood I spent mine own.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Ay, and much better blood than his or thine.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: In all which time you and your husband Grey
Were factious for the house of Lancaster;
And, Rivers, so were you. Was not your husband
In Margaret’s battle at Saint Albons slain?
Let me put in your minds, if you forget,
What you have been ere this, and what you are;
Withal, what I have been, and what I am.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: A murth’rous villain, and so still thou art.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Poor Clarence did forsake his father, Warwick,
Ay, and forswore himself—which Jesu pardon!—

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Which God revenge!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: To fight on Edward’s party for the crown,
And for his meed, poor lord, he is mewed up.
I would to God my heart were flint, like Edward’s,
Or Edward’s soft and pitiful, like mine:
I am too childish-foolish for this world.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Hie thee to hell for shame, and leave this world,
Thou cacodemon, there thy kingdom is.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days,
Which here you urge to prove us enemies,
We follow’d then our lord, our sovereign king.
So should we you, if you should be our king.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: If I should be? I had rather be a pedlar:
Far be it from my heart, the thought thereof!

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: As little joy, my lord, as you suppose
You should enjoy, were you this country’s king—
As little joy you may suppose in me
That I enjoy, being the queen thereof.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: A little joy enjoys the queen thereof,
For I am she, and altogether joyless.
I can no longer hold me patient.
Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out
In sharing that which you have pill’d from me!
Which of you trembles not that looks on me?
If not, that I am queen, you bow like subjects,
Yet that, by you depos’d, you quake like rebels?
Ah, gentle villain, do not turn away!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Foul wrinkled witch, what mak’st thou in my sight?

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: But repetition of what thou hast marr’d,
That will I make before I let thee go.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Wert thou not banished on pain of death?

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: I was; but I do find more pain in banishment
Than death can yield me here by my abode.
A husband and a son thou ow’st to me—
And thou a kingdom—all of you allegiance.
This sorrow that I have, by right is yours,
And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: The curse my noble father laid on thee
When thou didst crown his warlike brows with paper,
And with thy scorns drew’st rivers from his eyes,
And then, to dry them, gav’st the Duke a clout
Steep’d in the faultless blood of pretty Rutland—
His curses then, from bitterness of soul
Denounc’d against thee, are all fall’n upon thee;
And God, not we, hath plagu’d thy bloody deed.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: So just is God, to right the innocent.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: O, ’twas the foulest deed to slay that babe,
And the most merciless, that e’er was heard of!

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.

speech.speaker: DOR.
speech.line: No man but prophesied revenge for it.

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: Northumberland, then present, wept to see it.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: What? Were you snarling all before I came,
Ready to catch each other by the throat,
And turn you all your hatred now on me?
Did York’s dread curse prevail so much with heaven
That Henry’s death, my lovely Edward’s death,
Their kingdom’s loss, my woeful banishment,
Should all but answer for that peevish brat?
Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven?
Why then give way, dull clouds, to my quick curses!
Though not by war, by surfeit die your king,
As ours by murder, to make him a king!
Edward thy son, that now is Prince of Wales,
For Edward our son, that was Prince of Wales,
Die in his youth by like untimely violence!
Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen,
Outlive thy glory like my wretched self!
Long mayst thou live to wail thy children’s death,
And see another, as I see thee now,
Deck’d in thy rights as thou art stall’d in mine!
Long die thy happy days before thy death,
And after many length’ned hours of grief,
Die neither mother, wife, nor England’s queen!
Rivers and Dorset, you were standers-by,
And so wast thou, Lord Hastings, when my son
Was stabb’d with bloody daggers: God, I pray him
That none of you may live his natural age,
But by some unlook’d accident cut off!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Have done thy charm, thou hateful with’red hag.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: And leave out thee? Stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me.
If heaven have any grievous plague in store
Exceeding those that I can wish upon thee,
O, let them keep it till thy sins be ripe,
And then hurl down their indignation
On thee, the troubler of the poor world’s peace!
The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul!
Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou liv’st,
And take deep traitors for thy dearest friends!
No sleep close up that deadly eye of thine,
Unless it be while some tormenting dream
Affrights thee with a hell of ugly devils!
Thou elvish-mark’d, abortive, rooting hog!
Thou that wast seal’d in thy nativity
The slave of nature and the son of hell!
Thou slander of thy heavy mother’s womb!
Thou loathed issue of thy father’s loins!
Thou rag of honor! Thou detested—

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Margaret.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Richard!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Ha!

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: I call thee not.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I cry thee mercy then; for I did think
That thou hadst call’d me all these bitter names.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Why, so I did, but look’d for no reply.
O, let me make the period to my curse!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: ’Tis done by me, and ends in “Margaret.”

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Thus have you breath’d your curse against yourself.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune!
Why strew’st thou sugar on that bottled spider
Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about?
Fool, fool, thou whet’st a knife to kill thyself.
The day will come that thou shalt wish for me
To help thee curse this poisonous bunch-back’d toad.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse,
Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Foul shame upon you, you have all mov’d mine.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: Were you well serv’d, you would be taught your duty.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: To serve me well, you all should do me duty,
Teach me to be your queen, and you my subjects:
O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!

speech.speaker: DOR.
speech.line: Dispute not with her, she is lunatic.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Peace, Master Marquess, you are malapert,
Your fire-new stamp of honor is scarce current.
O that your young nobility could judge
What ’twere to lose it and be miserable!
They that stand high have many blasts to shake them,
And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Good counsel, marry! Learn it, learn it, Marquess.

speech.speaker: DOR.
speech.line: It touches you, my lord, as much as me.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Ay, and much more; but I was born so high,
Our aery buildeth in the cedar’s top
And dallies with the wind and scorns the sun.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: And turns the sun to shade—alas, alas!
Witness my son, now in the shade of death,
Whose bright out-shining beams thy cloudy wrath
Hath in eternal darkness folded up.
Your aery buildeth in our aery’s nest:
O God that seest it, do not suffer it!
As it is won with blood, lost be it so!

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: Peace, peace, for shame! If not, for charity.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: Urge neither charity nor shame to me.
Uncharitably with me have you dealt,
And shamefully my hopes, by you, are butcher’d.
My charity is outrage, life my shame,
And in that shame still live my sorrow’s rage!

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: Have done, have done.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: O princely Buckingham, I’ll kiss thy hand
In sign of league and amity with thee.
Now fair befall thee and thy noble house!
Thy garments are not spotted with our blood;
Nor thou within the compass of my curse.

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: Nor no one here; for curses never pass
The lips of those that breathe them in the air.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: I will not think but they ascend the sky,
And there awake God’s gentle-sleeping peace.
O Buckingham, take heed of yonder dog!
Look when he fawns he bites; and when he bites,
His venom tooth will rankle to the death.
Have not to do with him, beware of him;
Sin, death, and hell have set their marks on him,
And all their ministers attend on him.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: What doth she say, my Lord of Buckingham?

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.

speech.speaker: Q. MAR.
speech.line: What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel?
And soothe the devil that I warn thee from?
O but remember this another day,
When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow,
And say poor Margaret was a prophetess!
Live each of you the subjects to his hate,
And he to yours, and all of you to God’s!

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: My hair doth stand an end to hear her curses.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: And so doth mine. I muse why she’s at liberty.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I cannot blame her; by God’s holy Mother,
She hath had too much wrong, and I repent
My part thereof that I have done to her.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: I never did her any to my knowledge.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Yet you have all the vantage of her wrong.
I was too hot to do somebody good
That is too cold in thinking of it now.
Marry, as for Clarence, he is well repaid;
He is frank’d up to fatting for his pains—
God pardon them that are the cause thereof!

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion—
To pray for them that have done scathe to us.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: So do I ever—
being well advis’d;
For had I curs’d now, I had curs’d myself.

speech.speaker: CATE.
speech.line: Madam, his Majesty doth call for you,
And for your Grace, and yours, my gracious lord.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Catesby, I come. Lords, will you go with me?

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: We wait upon your Grace.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.
The secret mischiefs that I set abroach
I lay unto the grievous charge of others.
Clarence, who I indeed have cast in darkness,
I do beweep to many simple gulls—
Namely, to Derby, Hastings, Buckingham—
And tell them ’tis the Queen and her allies
That stir the King against the Duke my brother.
Now they believe it, and withal whet me
To be reveng’d on Rivers, Dorset, Grey.
But then I sigh, and, with a piece of scripture,
Tell them that God bids us do good for evil:
And thus I clothe my naked villainy
With odd old ends stol’n forth of holy writ,
And seem a saint, when most I play the devil.
But soft, here come my executioners.
How now, my hardy, stout, resolved mates,
Are you now going to dispatch this thing?

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: We are, my lord, and come to have the warrant,
That we may be admitted where he is.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Well thought upon, I have it here about me.
When you have done, repair to Crosby Place.
But, sirs, be sudden in the execution,
Withal obdurate, do not hear him plead;
For Clarence is well-spoken, and perhaps
May move your hearts to pity if you mark him.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Tut, tut, my lord, we will not stand to prate;
Talkers are no good doers. Be assur’d;
We go to use our hands, and not our tongues.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Your eyes drop millstones, when fools’ eyes fall tears.
I like you, lads, about your business straight.
Go, go, dispatch.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: We will, my noble lord.

scene.scenepersonae: (Clarence, Keeper, Brakenbury, Murderers)

speech.speaker: KEEP.
speech.line: Why looks your Grace so heavily today?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: O, I have pass’d a miserable night,
So full of fearful dreams, of ugly sights,
That, as I am a Christian faithful man,
I would not spend another such a night
Though ’twere to buy a world of happy days—
So full of dismal terror was the time.

speech.speaker: KEEP.
speech.line: What was your dream, my lord? I pray you tell me.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower
And was embark’d to cross to Burgundy,
And in my company my brother Gloucester,
Who from my cabin tempted me to walk
Upon the hatches. Thence we look’d toward England,
And cited up a thousand heavy times,
During the wars of York and Lancaster,
That had befall’n us. As we pac’d along
Upon the giddy footing of the hatches,
Methought that Gloucester stumbled, and in falling
Strook me (that thought to stay him) overboard
Into the tumbling billows of the main.
O Lord, methought what pain it was to drown!
What dreadful noise of waters in my ears!
What sights of ugly death within my eyes!
Methoughts I saw a thousand fearful wracks;
A thousand men that fishes gnaw’d upon;
Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl,
Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels,
All scatt’red in the bottom of the sea:
Some lay in dead men’s skulls, and in the holes
Where eyes did once inhabit, there were crept
(As ’twere in scorn of eyes) reflecting gems,
That woo’d the slimy bottom of the deep,
And mock’d the dead bones that lay scatt’red by.

speech.speaker: KEEP.
speech.line: Had you such leisure in the time of death
To gaze upon these secrets of the deep?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Methought I had, and often did I strive
To yield the ghost; but still the envious flood
Stopp’d in my soul, and would not let it forth
To find the empty, vast, and wand’ring air,
But smother’d it within my panting bulk,
Who almost burst to belch it in the sea.

speech.speaker: KEEP.
speech.line: Awak’d you not in this sore agony?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: No, no, my dream was lengthen’d after life.
O then began the tempest to my soul!
I pass’d (methought) the melancholy flood,
With that sour ferryman which poets write of,
Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.
The first that there did greet my stranger soul
Was my great father-in-law, renowned Warwick,
Who spake aloud, “What scourge for perjury
Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?”
And so he vanish’d. Then came wand’ring by
A shadow like an angel, with bright hair
Dabbled in blood, and he shriek’d out aloud,
“Clarence is come—false, fleeting, perjur’d Clarence,
That stabb’d me in the field by Tewksbury:
Seize on him, Furies, take him unto torment!”
With that (methoughts) a legion of foul fiends
Environ’d me, and howled in mine ears
Such hideous cries that with the very noise
I, trembling, wak’d, and for a season after
Could not believe but that I was in hell,
Such terrible impression made my dream.

speech.speaker: KEEP.
speech.line: No marvel, lord, though it affrighted you;
I am afraid (methinks) to hear you tell it.

speech.speaker: KEEP.
speech.line: Ah, Keeper, Keeper, I have done these things
(That now give evidence against my soul)
For Edward’s sake, and see how he requites me!
O God! If my deep pray’rs cannot appease thee,
But thou wilt be aveng’d on my misdeeds,
Yet execute thy wrath in me alone!
O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!
Keeper, I prithee sit by me awhile.
My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.

speech.speaker: KEEP.
speech.line: I will, my lord. God give your Grace good rest!

speech.speaker: BRAK.
speech.line: Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours,
Makes the night morning and the noontide night:
Princes have but their titles for their glories,
An outward honor for an inward toil,
And for unfelt imaginations
They often feel a world of restless cares;
So that between their titles and low name
There’s nothing differs but the outward fame.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Ho, who’s here?

speech.speaker: BRAK.
speech.line: What wouldst thou, fellow? And how cam’st thou hither?

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.

speech.speaker: BRAK.
speech.line: What, so brief?

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: ’Tis better, sir, than to be tedious. Let him see our commission, and talk no more.

speech.speaker: BRAK.
speech.line: I am in this commanded to deliver
The noble Duke of Clarence to your hands.
I will not reason what is meant hereby,
Because I will be guiltless from the meaning.
There lies the Duke asleep, and there the keys.
I’ll to the King and signify to him
That thus I have resign’d to you my charge.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: You may, sir, ’tis a point of wisdom. Fare you well.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: What, shall I stab him as he sleeps?

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: No, he’ll say ’twas done cowardly when he wakes.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Why, he shall never wake until the great Judgment Day.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Why, then he’ll say we stabb’d him sleeping.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: The urging of that word “judgment” hath bred a kind of remorse in me.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: What? Art thou afraid?

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Not to kill him, having a warrant, but to be damn’d for killing him, from the which no warrant can defend me.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: I thought thou hadst been resolute.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: So I am—to let him live.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: I’ll back to the Duke of Gloucester and tell him so.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Nay, I prithee stay a little. I hope this passionate humor of mine will change. It was wont to hold me but while one tells twenty.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: How dost thou feel thyself now?

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Remember our reward when the deed’s done.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: ’Zounds, he dies! I had forgot the reward.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Where’s thy conscience now?

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: O, in the Duke of Gloucester’s purse.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: When he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: ’Tis no matter, let it go. There’s few or none will entertain it.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: What if it come to thee again?

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: I’ll not meddle with it, it makes a man a coward. A man cannot steal, but it accuseth him; a man cannot swear, but it checks him; a man cannot lie with his neighbor’s wife, but it detects him. ’Tis a blushing shame-fac’d spirit that mutinies in a man’s bosom. It fills a man full of obstacles. It made me once restore a purse of gold that (by chance) I found. It beggars any man that keeps it. It is turn’d out of towns and cities for a dangerous thing, and every man that means to live well endeavors to trust to himself and live without it.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: ’Zounds, ’tis even now at my elbow, persuading me not to kill the Duke.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Take the devil in thy mind, and believe him not; he would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: I am strong-fram’d, he cannot prevail with me.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Spoke like a tall man that respects thy reputation. Come, shall we fall to work?

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Take him on the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then throw him into the malmsey-butt in the next room.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: O excellent device! And make a sop of him.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Soft, he wakes.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Strike!

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: No, we’ll reason with him.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Where art thou, Keeper? Give me a cup of wine.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: In God’s name, what art thou?

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: A man, as you are.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: But not, as I am, royal.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Nor you, as we are, loyal.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: My voice is now the King’s, my looks mine own.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: How darkly and how deadly dost thou speak!
Your eyes do menace me. Why look you pale?
Who sent you hither? Wherefore do you come?

speech.speaker: BOTH. 1. MUR. AND 2. MUR.
speech.line: To, to, to—

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: To murder me?

speech.speaker: BOTH. 1. MUR. AND 2. MUR.
speech.line: Ay, ay.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so,
And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it.
Wherein, my friends, have I offended you?

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Offended us you have not, but the King.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: I shall be reconcil’d to him again.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Never, my lord, therefore prepare to die.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Are you drawn forth among a world of men
To slay the innocent? What is my offense?
Where is the evidence that doth accuse me?
What lawful quest have given their verdict up
Unto the frowning judge? Or who pronounc’d
The bitter sentence of poor Clarence’ death?
Before I be convict by course of law,
To threaten me with death is most unlawful.
I charge you, as you hope to have redemption
By Christ’s dear blood shed for our grievous sins,
That you depart, and lay no hands on me.
The deed you undertake is damnable.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: What we will do, we do upon command.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: And he that hath commanded is our King.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Erroneous vassals, the great King of kings
Hath in the table of his law commanded
That thou shalt do no murder. Will you then
Spurn at his edict, and fulfill a man’s?
Take heed; for he holds vengeance in his hand,
To hurl upon their heads that break his law.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: And that same vengeance doth he hurl on thee
For false forswearing and for murder too.
Thou didst receive the sacrament to fight
In quarrel of the house of Lancaster.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: And like a traitor to the name of God
Didst break that vow, and with thy treacherous blade
Unrip’st the bowels of thy sov’reign’s son.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Whom thou wast sworn to cherish and defend.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: How canst thou urge God’s dreadful law to us,
When thou hast broke it in such dear degree?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Alas! For whose sake did I that ill deed?
For Edward, for my brother, for his sake.
He sends you not to murder me for this,
For in that sin he is as deep as I.
If God will be avenged for the deed,
O, know you yet he doth it publicly.
Take not the quarrel from his pow’rful arm;
He needs no indirect or lawless course
To cut off those that have offended him.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Who made thee then a bloody minister,
When gallant-springing brave Plantagenet,
That princely novice, was struck dead by thee?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: My brother’s love, the devil, and my rage.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Thy brother’s love, our duty, and thy faults
Provoke us hither now to slaughter thee.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: O, if you love my brother, hate not me!
I am his brother and I love him well.
If you are hir’d for meed, go back again,
And I will send you to my brother Gloucester,
Who shall reward you better for my life
Than Edward will for tidings of my death.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: You are deceiv’d, your brother Gloucester hates you.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: O no; he loves me and he holds me dear.
Go you to him from me.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Ay, so we will.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Tell him, when that our princely father York
Blest his three sons with his victorious arm,
And charg’d us from his soul to love each other,)
He little thought of this divided friendship.
Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Ay, millstones, as he lesson’d us to weep.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: O, do not slander him, for he is kind.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Right, as snow in harvest. Come, you deceive yourself,
’Tis he that sends us to destroy you here.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: It cannot be, for he bewept my fortune,
And hugg’d me in his arms, and swore with sobs
That he would labor my delivery.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Why, so he doth, when he delivers you
From this earth’s thralldom to the joys of heaven.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Have you that holy feeling in your souls
To counsel me to make my peace with God,
And are you yet to your own souls so blind
That you will war with God by murd’ring me?
O, sirs, consider, they that set you on
To do this deed will hate you for the deed.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: What shall we do?

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Relent, and save your souls.
Which of you, if you were a prince’s son,
Being pent from liberty, as I am now,
If two such murderers as yourselves came to you,
Would not entreat for life?

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Relent? No: ’tis cowardly and womanish.

speech.speaker: CLAR.
speech.line: Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish.
My friend
I spy some pity in thy looks.
O, if thine eye be not a flatterer,
Come thou on my side, and entreat for me,
As you would beg, were you in my distress.
A begging prince what beggar pities not?

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: Look behind you, my lord.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: Take that! And that!
If all this will not do,
I’ll drown you in the malmsey-butt within.

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: A bloody deed, and desperately dispatch’d!
How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my hands
Of this most grievous murder!

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: How now? What mean’st thou, that thou help’st me not?
By heavens, the Duke shall know how slack you have been!

speech.speaker: 2. MUR.
speech.line: I would he knew that I had sav’d his brother!
Take thou the fee and tell him what I say,
For I repent me that the Duke is slain.

speech.speaker: 1. MUR.
speech.line: So do not I. Go, coward as thou art.
Well, I’ll go hide the body in some hole
Till that the Duke give order for his burial;
And when I have my meed, I will away,
For this will out, and then I must not stay.

scene.scenepersonae: (King Edward, Queen Elizabeth, Lord Marquess Dorset, Rivers, Hastings, Catesby, Buckingham, Grey, Ratcliffe, Gloucester, Stanley)
scene.stagedir: Flourish. Enter the King Edward sick, the Queen Elizabeth, Lord Marquess Dorset, Rivers, Hastings, Catesby, Buckingham, Grey, and others.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Why, so: now have I done a good day’s work.
You peers, continue this united league.
I every day expect an embassage
From my Redeemer to redeem me hence;
And more in peace my soul shall part to heaven,
Since I have made my friends at peace on earth.
Hastings and Rivers, take each other’s hand,
Dissemble not your hatred, swear your love.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: By heaven, my soul is purg’d from grudging hate,
And with my hand I seal my true heart’s love.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: So thrive I, as I truly swear the like!

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Take heed you dally not before your king,
Lest He that is the supreme King of kings
Confound your hidden falsehood and award
Either of you to be the other’s end.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: So prosper I, as I swear perfect love!

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: And I, as I love Hastings with my heart!

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Madam, yourself is not exempt from this;
Nor you, son Dorset; Buckingham, nor you;
You have been factious one against the other.
Wife, love Lord Hastings, let him kiss your hand,
And what you do, do it unfeignedly.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: There, Hastings, I will never more remember
Our former hatred, so thrive I and mine!

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Dorset, embrace him; Hastings, love Lord Marquess.

speech.speaker: DOR.
speech.line: This interchange of love, I here protest,
Upon my part shall be inviolable.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: And so swear I.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league
With thy embracements to my wive’s allies,
And make me happy in your unity.

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: When ever Buckingham doth turn his hate
Upon your Grace
But with all duteous love
Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me
With hate in those where I expect most love!
When I have most need to employ a friend,
And most assured that he is a friend,
Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile
Be he unto me! This do I beg of God,
When I am cold in love to you or yours.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham,
Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart.
There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here
To make the blessed period of this peace.

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: And in good time,
Here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe and the Duke.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen,
And, princely peers, a happy time of day!

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Happy indeed, as we have spent the day.
Gloucester, we have done deeds of charity,
Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate,
Between these swelling wrong-incensed peers.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: A blessed labor, my most sovereign lord.
Among this princely heap, if any here
By false intelligence or wrong surmise
Hold me a foe—
If I unwittingly, or in my rage,
Have aught committed that is hardly borne
By any in this presence, I desire
To reconcile me to his friendly peace.
’Tis death to me to be at enmity;
I hate it, and desire all good men’s love.
First, madam, I entreat true peace of you,
Which I will purchase with my duteous service;
Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham,
If ever any grudge were lodg’d between us;
Of you, and you, Lord Rivers, and of Dorset,
That all without desert have frown’d on me;
Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen—indeed of all.
I do not know that Englishman alive
With whom my soul is any jot at odds
More than the infant that is born tonight.
I thank my God for my humility.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter.
I would to God all strifes were well compounded.
My sovereign lord, I do beseech your Highness
To take our brother Clarence to your grace.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Why, madam, have I off’red love for this,
To be so flouted in this royal presence?
Who knows not that the gentle Duke is dead?
You do him injury to scorn his corse.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Who knows not he is dead? Who knows he is?

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: All-seeing heaven, what a world is this!

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?

speech.speaker: DOR.
speech.line: Ay, my good lord, and no man in the presence
But his red color hath forsook his cheeks.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Is Clarence dead? The order was revers’d.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: But he, poor man, by your first order died,
And that a winged Mercury did bear;
Some tardy cripple bare the countermand,
That came too lag to see him buried.
God grant that some, less noble and less loyal,
Nearer in bloody thoughts, but not in blood,
Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did,
And yet go current from suspicion!

speech.speaker: STAN.
speech.line: A boon, my sovereign, for my service done!

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: I prithee peace, my soul is full of sorrow.

speech.speaker: STAN.
speech.line: I will not rise, unless your Highness hear me.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Then say at once what is it thou requests.

speech.speaker: STAN.
speech.line: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant’s life,
Who slew today a riotous gentleman
Lately attendant on the Duke of Norfolk.

speech.speaker: K. EDW.
speech.line: Have I a tongue to doom my brother’s death,
And shall that tongue give pardon to a slave?
My brother kill’d no man, his fault was thought,
And yet his punishment was bitter death.
Who sued to me for him? Who (in my wrath)
Kneel’d at my feet and bid me be advis’d?
Who spoke of brotherhood? Who spoke of love?
Who told me how the poor soul did forsake
The mighty Warwick and did fight for me?
Who told me, in the field at Tewksbury,
When Oxford had me down, he rescued me,
And said, “Dear brother, live, and be a king”?
Who told me, when we both lay in the field
Frozen (almost) to death, how he did lap me
Even in his own garments, and did give himself
(All thin and naked) to the numb cold night?
All this from my remembrance brutish wrath
Sinfully pluck’d, and not a man of you
Had so much grace to put it in my mind.
But when your carters or your waiting vassals
Have done a drunken slaughter, and defac’d
The precious image of our dear Redeemer,
You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon,
And I (unjustly too) must grant it you.
But for my brother not a man would speak,
Nor I (ungracious) speak unto myself
For him, poor soul. The proudest of you all
Have been beholding to him in his life;
Yet none of you would once beg for his life.
O God! I fear thy justice will take hold
On me and you, and mine and yours, for this.
Come, Hastings, help me to my closet. Ah, poor Clarence!

scene.stagedir: Exeunt some with King and Queen.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: This is the fruits of rashness! Mark’d you not
How that the guilty kindred of the Queen
Look’d pale when they did hear of Clarence’ death?
O, they did urge it still unto the King!
God will revenge it. Come, lords, will you go
To comfort Edward with our company.

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: We wait upon your Grace.

scene.scenepersonae: (Duchess of York, Edward Plantagenet, Margaret Plantagenet, Queen Elizabeth, Rivers, Dorset, Richard, Buckingham, Derby, Hastings, Ratcliffe)
scene.stagedir: Enter the old Duchess of York with the two children of Clarence (Edward and Margaret Plantagenet).

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Good grandam, tell us, is our father dead?

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: No, boy.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Why do you weep so oft, and beat your breast,
And cry, “O Clarence, my unhappy son!”?

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Why do you look on us, and shake your head,
And call us orphans, wretches, castaways,
If that our noble father were alive?

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: My pretty cousins, you mistake me both:
I do lament the sickness of the King,
As loath to lose him, not your father’s death;
It were lost sorrow to wail one that’s lost.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Then you conclude, my grandam, he is dead.
The King mine uncle is to blame for it.
God will revenge it, whom I will importune
With earnest prayers all to that effect.

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: And so will I.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: Peace, children, peace, the King doth love you well.
Incapable and shallow innocents,
You cannot guess who caus’d your father’s death.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Grandam, we can; for my good uncle Gloucester
Told me the King, provok’d to it by the Queen,
Devis’d impeachments to imprison him;
And when my uncle told me so, he wept,
And pitied me, and kindly kiss’d my cheek;
Bade me rely on him as on my father,
And he would love me dearly as a child.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: Ah! That deceit should steal such gentle shape,
And with a virtuous visor hide deep vice!
He is my son—ay, and therein my shame,
Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: Ay, boy.

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: I cannot think it. Hark, what noise is this?

scene.stagedir: Enter the Queen Elizabeth with her hair about her ears; Rivers and Dorset after her.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Ah! Who shall hinder me to wail and weep,
To chide my fortune, and torment myself?
I’ll join with black despair against my soul,
And to myself become an enemy.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: What means this scene of rude impatience?

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: To make an act of tragic violence.
Edward, my lord, thy son, our king, is dead!
Why grow the branches when the root is gone?
Why wither not the leaves that want their sap?
If you will live, lament; if die, be brief,
That our swift-winged souls may catch the King’s,
Or like obedient subjects follow him
To his new kingdom of ne’er-changing night.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: Ah, so much interest have I in thy sorrow
As I had title in thy noble husband!
I have bewept a worthy husband’s death,
And liv’d with looking on his images;
But now two mirrors of his princely semblance
Are crack’d in pieces by malignant death,
And I for comfort have but one false glass,
That grieves me when I see my shame in him.
Thou art a widow; yet thou art a mother,
And hast the comfort of thy children left;
But death hath snatch’d my husband from mine arms,
And pluck’d two crutches from my feeble hands,
Clarence and Edward. O, what cause have I
(Thine being but a moi’ty of my moan)
To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries!

speech.speaker: EDW.
speech.line: Ah, aunt! You wept not for our father’s death;
How can we aid you with our kindred tears?

speech.speaker: MARG.
speech.line: Our fatherless distress was left unmoan’d,
Your widow-dolor likewise be unwept!

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Give me no help in lamentation,
I am not barren to bring forth complaints.
All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes,
That I being govern’d by the watery moon,
May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world!
Ah for my husband, for my dear Lord Edward!

speech.speaker: CHIL.
speech.line: Ah for our father, for our dear Lord Clarence!

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: What stay had I but Edward? And he’s gone.

speech.speaker: CHIL.
speech.line: What stay had we but Clarence? And he’s gone.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: What stays had I but they? And they are gone.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Was never widow had so dear a loss.

speech.speaker: CHIL.
speech.line: Were never orphans had so dear a loss.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: Was never mother had so dear a loss.
Alas! I am the mother of these griefs:
Their woes are parcell’d, mine is general.
She for an Edward weeps, and so do I;
I for a Clarence weep, so doth not she;
These babes for Clarence weep, and so do I;
I for an Edward weep, so do not they.
Alas! You three on me, threefold distress’d,
Pour all your tears. I am your sorrow’s nurse,
And I will pamper it with lamentation.

speech.speaker: DOR.
speech.line: Comfort, dear mother, God is much displeas’d
That you take with unthankfulness his doing.
In common worldly things ’tis call’d ungrateful
With dull unwillingness to repay a debt,
Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent;
Much more to be thus opposite with heaven,
For it requires the royal debt it lent you.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: Madam, bethink you like a careful mother
Of the young Prince your son. Send straight for him,
Let him be crown’d, in him your comfort lives.
Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward’s grave,
And plant your joys in living Edward’s throne.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard of Gloucester, Buckingham, Stanley Earl of Derby, Hastings, and Ratcliffe.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Sister, have comfort. All of us have cause
To wail the dimming of our shining star;
But none can help our harms by wailing them.
Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy,
I did not see your Grace. Humbly on my knee
I crave your blessing.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: God bless thee, and put meekness in thy breast,
Love, charity, obedience, and true duty!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Amen!—
And make me die a good old man!
That is the butt-end of a mother’s blessing.
I marvel that her Grace did leave it out.

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers
That bear this heavy mutual load of moan,
Now cheer each other in each other’s love.
Though we have spent our harvest of this king,
We are to reap the harvest of his son.
The broken rancor of your high-swoll’n hates,
But lately splinter’d, knit, and join’d together,
Must gently be preserv’d, cherish’d, and kept.
Me seemeth good that, with some little train,
Forthwith from Ludlow the young Prince be fet
Hither to London, to be crown’d our king.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: Why with some little train, my Lord of Buckingham?

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: Marry, my lord, lest by a multitude
The new-heal’d wound of malice should break out,
Which would be so much the more dangerous,
By how much the estate is green and yet ungovern’d.
Where every horse bears his commanding rein
And may direct his course as please himself,
As well the fear of harm, as harm apparent,
In my opinion, ought to be prevented.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I hope the King made peace with all of us,
And the compact is firm and true in me.

speech.speaker: RIV.
speech.line: And so in me, and so (I think) in all.
Yet since it is but green, it should be put
To no apparent likelihood of breach,
Which haply by much company might be urg’d;
Therefore I say with noble Buckingham,
That it is meet so few should fetch the Prince.

speech.speaker: HAST.
speech.line: And so say I.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Then be it so, and go we to determine
Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow.
Madam, and you, my sister, will you go
To give your censures in this business?

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ., DUCH.
speech.line: With all our hearts.

speech.speaker: BUCK.
speech.line: My lord, whoever journeys to the Prince,
For God sake let not us two stay at home;
For by the way, I’ll sort occasion,
As index to the story we late talk’d of,
To part the Queen’s proud kindred from the Prince.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: My other self, my counsel’s consistory,
My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin,
I, as a child, will go by thy direction.
Toward Ludlow then, for we’ll not stay behind.

scene.scenepersonae: (Three Citizens)
scene.stagedir: Enter one Citizen at one door and another at the other.

speech.speaker: 1. CIT.
speech.line: Good morrow, neighbor, whither away so fast?

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
speech.line: I promise you, I scarcely know myself.
Hear you the news abroad?

speech.speaker: 1. CIT.
speech.line: Yes, that the King is dead.

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
speech.line: Ill news, by’r lady—seldom comes the better.
I fear, I fear ’twill prove a giddy world.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: Neighbors, God speed!

speech.speaker: 1. CIT.
speech.line: Give you good morrow, sir.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: Doth the news hold of good King Edward’s death?

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
speech.line: Ay, sir, it is too true, God help the while!

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.

speech.speaker: 1. CIT.
speech.line: No, no, by God’s good grace his son shall reign.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: Woe to that land that’s govern’d by a child!

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
speech.line: In him there is a hope of government,
Which in his nonage, council under him,
And in his full and ripened years, himself,
No doubt shall then, and till then, govern well.

speech.speaker: 1. CIT.
speech.line: So stood the state when Henry the Sixth
Was crown’d in Paris but at nine months old.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: Stood the state so? No, no, good friends, God wot,
For then this land was famously enrich’d
With politic grave counsel; then the King
Had virtuous uncles to protect his Grace.

speech.speaker: 1. CIT.
speech.line: Why, so hath this, both by his father and mother.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: Better it were they all came by his father,
Or by his father there were none at all;
For emulation who shall now be nearest
Will touch us all too near, if God prevent not.
O, full of danger is the Duke of Gloucester,
And the Queen’s sons and brothers haught and proud!
And were they to be rul’d, and not to rule,
This sickly land might solace as before.

speech.speaker: 1. CIT.
speech.line: Come, come, we fear the worst; all will be well.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: When clouds are seen, wise men put on their cloaks;
When great leaves fall, then winter is at hand;
When the sun sets, who doth not look for night?
Untimely storms makes men expect a dearth.
All may be well; but if God sort it so,
’Tis more than we deserve or I expect.

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
speech.line: Truly, the hearts of men are full of fear.
You cannot reason (almost) with a man
That looks not heavily and full of dread.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: Before the days of change, still is it so.
By a divine instinct men’s minds mistrust
Ensuing danger; as by proof we see
The water swell before a boist’rous storm.
But leave it all to God. Whither away?

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
speech.line: Marry, we were sent for to the justices.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: And so was I. I’ll bear you company.

scene.scenepersonae: (Archbishop of York, Duke of York, Queen Elizabeth, Duchess of York, Messenger to the Queen)
scene.stagedir: Enter Archbishop of York, the young Duke of York, the Queen Elizabeth, and the Duchess of York.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Last night, I hear, they lay at Stony-Stratford,
And at Northampton they do rest tonight.
Tomorrow, or next day, they will be here.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: I long with all my heart to see the Prince.
I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: But I hear no; they say my son of York
Has almost overta’en him in his growth.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Ay, mother, but I would not have it so.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: Why, my good cousin, it is good to grow.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper,
My uncle Rivers talk’d how I did grow
More than my brother. “Ay,” quoth my uncle Gloucester,
“Small herbs have grace, great weeds do grow apace.”
And since, methinks I would not grow so fast,
Because sweet flow’rs are slow and weeds make haste.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold
In him that did object the same to thee:
He was the wretched’st thing when he was young,
So long a-growing and so leisurely
That if his rule were true, he should be gracious.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: I hope he is, but yet let mothers doubt.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Now by my troth, if I had been rememb’red,
I could have given my uncle’s Grace a flout,
To touch his growth nearer than he touch’d mine.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: How, my young York? I prithee let me hear it.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Marry (they say) my uncle grew so fast
That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old;
’Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.
Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: I prithee, pretty York, who told thee this?

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Grandam, his nurse.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: His nurse? Why, she was dead ere thou wast born.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: If ’twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: A parlous boy! Go to, you are too shrewd.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: Good madam, be not angry with the child.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: Pitchers have ears.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: Here comes a messenger. What news?

speech.speaker: MESS. QUEEN.
speech.line: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to report.

speech.speaker: Q. ELIZ.
speech.line: How doth the Prince?

speech.speaker: MESS. QUEEN.
speech.line: Well, madam, and in health.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: What is thy news?

speech.speaker: MESS. QUEEN.
speech.line: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret,
And with them Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.

speech.speaker: DUCH.
speech.line: Who hath committed them?

speech.speaker: MESS. QUEEN.
speech.line: The mighty dukes,
Gloucester and Buckingham.

speech.speaker: ARCH.
speech.line: For what offense?

speech.speaker: MESS. QUEEN.
speech.line: The sum of all I can I have disclos’d.
Why, or for what, the nobles were committed
Is all unknown to me, my gracious lord.
